title: Non Governmental Public Action Networks and Global Policy Processes
abstractText:
This project addresses the transnational policy activities of research networks, university institutes and think tanks. The creators and distributors of policy knowledge – scientific theories, concepts and models, data sets and statistics, policy analysis – are central players in the weak institutional context of global and regional governance.

The research inquires into the manner in which knowledge institutions deliver conceptual understanding of policy problems; how networks set policy agendas; and the effectiveness and legitimacy with which they implement and monitor public action beyond the nation-state. Questions asked in this project include:

  • How and why have researchers and their organisations become trans-national?
  • What is the nature of knowledge demand from international organisations, governments, multilateral initiatives and global policy networks?
  • What is the role of knowledge producers in agenda setting, standards setting, and policy evaluation?
  • Which knowledge institutions are perceived as ‘expert’ and ‘elite’?  And through what socio-political processes can ‘expertness’ be constructed?

The method is a desk based investigation along side participant observation in the conferences, workshops and other activities of four case study organisations:

  • The Global Development Network
  • The Overseas Development Institute
  • The Open Society Institute
  • The ASEAN Institutes of Strategic and International Studies
